Legal system: the laws of Norway, where applicable, apply
Location: Northern Europe, island between the Greenland Sea and the Norwegian Sea, northeast of Iceland
Maritime claims: 200 m depth or to the depth of exploitation
Natural hazards: Beerenberg (elev. 2,227 m) is Norway's only active volcano; volcanic activity resumed in 1970; the most recent eruption occurred in 1985
Dependency status: territory of Norway; since August 1994, administered from Oslo through the county governor (fylkesmann) of Nordland; however, authority has been delegated to a station commander of the Norwegian Defense Communication Service
Flag description: the flag of Norway is used
Area - comparative: slightly more than twice the size of Washington, DC
Population: personnel operate the Long Range Navigation (Loran-C) base and the weather and coastal services radio station
Climate: arctic maritime with frequent storms and persistent fog
Elevation extremes: Haakon VII Toppen on Beerenberg 2,277 m
Beerenberg volcano has numerous peaks; the highest point on the volcano rim is named Haakon VII Toppen, after Norway's first king following the reestablishment of Norwegian independence in 1905
Military - note: defense is the responsibility of Norway
Terrain: volcanic island, partly covered by glaciers
Geography - note: barren volcanic island with some moss and grass
Broadcast media: a coastal radio station has been remotely operated since 1994 (2008)
